name: 1959 wheel
notes: Very early wheel. Larger vents and riveted. Used until about september '61. Later wheels were spotwelded as the rivets proofed unreliable.

name: LP888
notes: 60's standard wheel Part 21A881

name: 21A2744
notes: 70's standard wheel

name: Fergat
notes: Std. steel wheel made by Fergat for Innocenti.

name: Firestone
notes: Std. steel wheel, this time made by Firestone.

name: Firsat
notes: Made for Innocenti Minis. Stamping: 1004.

name: Lemmerz E1029
notes: Copy of the LP882

name: Lemmerz E1030
notes: Holes like LP882 but has the standard rim's offset!

name: Early LP883
notes: Hubcap clamps/noses welded on! There's another version without clamps/noses, propably for competiton purposes (where hubcaps are not neccesary).

name: Fergat
notes: Identical to LP883, this one is from 1968

name: Griffin
notes: Copy of the LP882, made of alloy. Manufactured by Griffin (JAP).

name: Griffin
notes: Another copy of the LP883, made of alloy. Manufactured by Griffin (JAP) and sold at Minisport UK

name: Dunlop LP918/'reverse rims'
notes: Those wheels were never a standard fitment. But they were available by aftermarked dealers. And by Leyland ST. Wheels sold by Leyland ST are not stamped 'LP918', but 'AHT182' (Leyland ST part C-AHT182).

name: Dunlop LP918/'reverse rims', chromed
notes: Chromed and riveted instead of being welded

name: Dunlop LP918/'reverse rims'
notes: Ultra rare 5 - reverse rim.

name: Reproduktion of LP882
notes: Reproduction of the sought after 3.5" 'S' wheel. Sold by both MiniSport and MiniSpares UK. Look in the link section!

name: Reproduktion of LP883
notes: About £60 inc VAT: Sold by both MiniSport and MiniSpares UK. Look in the link section!

name: Firsat
notes: Can you spot the difference? Smal immersions around the spokes.

name: CMR
notes: Smal immersions around spokes. But note: both CMR and Firsat came either with or without them, there's no fast rule.

name: Firestone
notes: Same wheel, different manufacturer. 'Firestone 4½Jx10 1 75' stamped into outer rim.

name: Fergat
notes: Same wheel, this time by Fergat. This wheels were used on late Authi 1300 Coopers, the cousin of the Innocenti Cooper 1300. Earlyer wheels were plain silver, the later ones got a two tone colour (black/silver).

name: LP883 lookalike
notes: Made of alloy. Made to fit over 8.4" brake. NOTE: It has a HUGE offset, so the rim fits not over the brake but literaly stands BESIDE the brake caliper! Needs BIG wheel arches (Sportspack)! Sold at Minispeed UK Note: It looks like there are TWO versions of this wheel! One with ET-15 to fit over 8.4" discs, and one with ET14 which does NOT clear the 8.4" discs, but any 7.5 & 7.9" discs!

name: Unknown'
notes: Not much is know yet, they seem to come from Italy. Probably a aftermarket replacement wheel.

name: Cyclone Wheels
notes: Made in the 60's.

name: Reverse rims
notes: Standard wheel centres, available too!

name: Weller reverse rim
notes: Made by Weller, but with standart 3.5" wheel centre with its stampings!

name: Weller reverse rim
notes: Half an inch wider...

name: Weller reverse rim
notes: One inch wider...

name: Weller
notes: Note: Not 100% sure, wheter they are Weller (not dished!).

name: Weller four spoke
notes: Not the official name but to differentiate from other Weller wheels named "four spoke".

name: Weller five spoke
notes: Not the official name but to differentiate from other Weller wheels named "five spoke".Very similar to the above 4 spoke wheel, but with on spoke more. Spokey!

name: Weller
notes: Only 50 ever made for single seater race cars in the USA.

name: California Star(?), chromed
notes: Weller copy or Weller? Named 'California Star' at back.

name: Manx
notes: Weller look-a-like

name: Jolly
notes: Another Weller look-a-like

name: Cooper Car Company 'Rosepetal'
notes: The original 8 spoke design wheel. Made by the Cooper Car Company. It's a 'copy' of the wheels used by Cooper   for Formula racers. The Minilite design was copied from the 'Rosepetal', but is more famous today.

name: Rosepetal
notes: Picture (c) Casper Sparsöe. | Made for 18 times Danish Champ winner Erik Hoejer by Ole Rytter (Denmark). The same man who also, in '66-'68, made the first alloy 7 port heads,   which were the brainchild of Erik Hoejer's race mechanic Poul Heickendorff. The heads which later became the base for the iron copys by AKM (and then MiniSport).   Only 2 sets know to exist.

name: Rosepetal', recast
notes: 80's Cooper Car Co. cast of the Rosepetal

name: Vortz 'Rosepetal'
notes: Vortz bought the Cooper Car Co's original tooling and continues to make the 'original' Rosepetal. Added 'Vortz' logo on oter edge.

name: Vortz 'Rosepetal'
notes: Limited batch made without the 'Vortz' logo.

name: MiniSpares Center 'Rosepetal'
notes: Modern reproduktion by MiniSpares Ltd. Part n° C-21A1071.

name: CR wheels
notes: Fit w/ 165/70 tyres w/out arches Still in production in smal numbers in Japan. Copy of the famous Rose Petals

name: Early Minilite Magnesium
notes: The groove dissapeared ~1967

name: Minilite Generation II
notes: Modern designed, 'dished' Minilite. 3.4kg.

name: Span Mag
notes: Made in New Zealand by Papakura Metal Foundry. Available in a range of widths up to 9inches.

name: Ward
notes: Originally made as Ward wheels in Palmerston North  N.Z.  Were later made better and with a nicer finish by Aldic and   became regulation wheel for N.Z. Mini seven racing, Group NB.

name: Fraser
notes: Again a copy of the Ward wheel. Fraser made about 100 of them. Any more info greatly appreciated!

name: Mini<u>life</u> works replica
notes: Fits without wheel arch extensions.

name: BWA Racing 'GB', later design
notes: Commonly only known as 'GB'. Manufactured by 'BWA Racing'

name: Boomerang
notes: Italian made

name: Unknown 46
notes: Unknown Minilite-Style wheel, most probably from Italy. No marks. Can anyone identifie this wheel? Looks similar to the   Carmona, but has much smaler seats for nuts. Nuts are a combination of sleeve & tapered seat.

name: MWS
notes: This 5X10 wheel was designed for use with drum brakes and will not fit the Cooper S brake.

name: PEG Mistral

name: ROH 'Contesta'

name: ROH 'Contesta'

name: Unknown 50

name: Amos mags

name: Asso Mini

name: ATS

name: ATS
notes: Survey for German TÜV

name: Avon Safety Wheels
notes: The Avon Safety Wheel avoids the detachment of a deflated tyre by having a much shallower central recess   within the interior of the wheel. The recess is so shallow that the tyre is prevented from twisting, what   would allow it to slip over the edge of the rim, so it is retained. Such a shallow recess would   also prevent the fitment of new tyres, if it weren't for the inclusion of a deep channel, allowing the bead   of the tyre to enter the channel to permit fitting. The channel is covered by a metal band that is tightened   around the wheel after the tyre is fitted but before it is inflated.

name: Avenger
notes: From South Africa, probably 80's.

name: Bachtel
notes: Swiss made!

name: Borrani 'Dial'
notes: Yes; Borrani didn't do wire wheels only! In the 60's & 70's they made a range of alloy wheels too.

name: CMW split rims
notes: Comes in two forms: with the center spokes either behind or in front of the mounting lip.   They are lighter than true Minilight magnesium wheels of the same size.

name: Canonica (by Fondmetal)

name: D&A Engineering
notes: This wheel has a lettering on the inseide; "D&A ENGINEERING LTD. OF SURBITON". And some subtle differences in the center cap area.   The center cap hole seems smaler and recessed. This is subject of speculation; but probably D&A Engineering bought the original moulds from GKN when   the original wheel was discontinued. If anyone can shed more light on this, I'm happy to hear about!

name: E-T 'cross wire'
notes: Made in the 60's and 70's by E-T in California. They still sell classic drag and race wheels under the 'E-T' brand, the manufacturer is called   'Team III Wheels' today.

name: Edgar Schwyn
notes: Edgar Schwyn was a Swiss tuner. Apparently he designed & sold this wheel which was then produced by another company (not uncommon as a own fundry   is not economical for smal batches of wheels).

name: Same design as above, but no lettering at all.
notes: Seemingly this is the same wheel as the 'Edgar Schwyn' wheel. Maybe Edgar Schwyn had a batch made under his own name but the (unknown)   manufacturer sold they'r own unbranded version of the wheel? If anyone has anymore information about it - I'm very glad to hear about! :-)

name: ESAP
notes: Three piece modular split wheel. ESAP was a divison from 'Speedline'.

name: Maifrini Mille Miglia MkI

name: Mamba, 8x10
notes: This is an sand cast 8" wheel used on a 'Terrapin' single seater racer in the late 60's. Allan Staniforth and some friends where in desperate need   of some wide wheels for theyr Terrapin single seaters. After banded steel wheels got banned by the regulations, they decided to cast theyr own wheels.   That's how the 'Mamba' project started. There where probably less than 30 8" wheels being cast (sand cast by hand!). At the time being, it was as light   and solid as a magnesium Minilite, but much cheaper to get - so it got quite a popular wheel back then and still is.

name: Mamba
notes: Mamba lightweight alloy wheels were made by John Thornton, back around 1966-67. They were designed for Minis and were available   in 5", 5 1/2" & 6" as standard. Any other size on special order; these large sizes were used on single seaters of the day. John Thornton was also   a friend of Alan Staniforth the designer/constructor of a Mini-based world record holding home made single seater called the Terrapin.   The Mamba project was sold in the early 70's and has passed through many hands since, the last firm to make Mambas was probably MWS some years ago.

name: Mamba
notes: The early edition had valve stem "inside" rim hidden amongst the spokes (see above) while later version had valve stem in outer rim.   The wheel pictured is believed to be a very late made wheel due to the general 'softer' appearance.

name: Mamba
notes: There are japanese copys around; the main difference is where the valve comes out of the rim,    the "real" ones come out straight from the outer rim and the japanese ones come out of the black bit and on a 45° angle     Also available a

name: Mamba
notes: The newest reincarnation of the Mamba wheel. Sold by MiniSpares and MiniMania (US).

name: Mamba

name: Another rim from TheMiniMan

name: Momo
notes: The 4 Momo wheels below are sold by MOMO, but not cast by Momo. Momo did never have a foundry. So they might be cast by a big company like FONDMETAL. There's still much reasearch to do. There's actually no proof yet who realy did cast them. So it depends of what you call them... Momos, Fondmetals, - they seem to be commonly known as both. Centrecaps part of casting, clamped in lid, as opposed to the next wheel.

name: Momo
notes: Those have cast '5.00x10' and '2r' into the outer lip.   Although they look masive and heavy, they are comparably light; 3.3kg/wheel.

name: Momo
notes: Same markings, but in different orientation.

name: Momo
notes: Real hubcaps instead of cast in raising with clamped in metal lid. Some are stamped 'Made in italy, MomoJ'. It seems they came   in two widths? I know a set which is 5.75" wide and one that is 6".

name: Momo
